Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: The COVID-19 Pandemic Seattle, Washington Street View Campaign

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Seattle, Washington is the first city in the United States to be severely impacted by the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic. Since the outbreak, state and local governments have enacted policies and guidelines (i.e., nonpharmaceutical interventions) to stem the spread of the disease, including a statewide shelter-in-place order. This Grant for Rapid Response Research (RAPID) will conduct longitudinal (repeat) street view surveys for 12 months across a broad cross-section of Seattle to collect data on the community impact of the pandemic. The survey campaign will produce a high-resolution, ground-based record of the urban region both during and after this pandemic. The data set will provide fundamental insights on (1) disaster impacts on business operations, transportation networks, and other community assets, (2) the rate and quality of recovery following shelter-in-place, and how this varies locally based on a community's socioeconomic characteristics, and (3) the impact of shelter-in-place policy relaxation on communities following this disaster. In addition to the data collection, this project will advance the scientific application of post-event mobile imaging by establishing sampling protocols that may be used to guide data collection campaigns for future disruptive events. All project data will be made openly available to research and practice communities in the NSF-supported Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure (NHERI) Date Depot (https://www.Designsafe-ci.org).

The street view surveys will be conducted using the NSF-supported NHERI RAPID facility's vehicle-mounted mobile imaging system, located at the University of Washington. Two data collection strategies will be adopted: (1) canvassing, an umbrella approach to acquire data that may be used to answer diverse multidisciplinary research questions, and (2) surveying across community capitals transects (social, cultural, built, economic, and public health), an approach grounded in capital-based resilience theory to promote the capacity for replication across a wide range of communities and hazards. The project will also develop and implement a series of open-source routines that automatically process the data to rapidly extract time-sensitive insights from the imagery. The processed data set will serve as a benchmark for calibrating and validating urban simulation and recovery models and many of the emerging artificial intelligence-based models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research team developed an innovative method to collect and analyze street-level imagery data over time, providing valuable insights into community mobility patterns during the COVID-19 pandemic. This project addressed a significant gap in existing data collection methods and demonstrated the potential for widespread applications in urban research, public health, and disaster response.

The core of our work involved creating an open-source data pipeline that processes 360-degree video recorded from a car-mounted camera. This system generates high-quality street view images that can be analyzed to track changes in pedestrian traffic and other urban features over time. We collected data across Seattle, Washington for 38 months during the pandemic, resulting in over 4 million images.

Our approach offers several advantages over existing methods:

1. Temporal consistency: Unlike corporate street view databases that update infrequently, our method allows for regular data collection to track changes over time.

2. Broad coverage: By using a mobile camera setup, we can efficiently survey large urban areas.

3. Open access: Our open-source pipeline allows researchers to collect their own data, reducing reliance on corporate-owned imagery.

4. Privacy protection: Our system automatically blurs faces to protect individual privacy.

The intellectual merit of this work lies in its novel approach to longitudinal urban data collection and analysis. We developed sophisticated computer vision techniques to detect and count pedestrians in the images, allowing us to quantify changes in community mobility throughout the pandemic. Our statistical analyses revealed several important findings:

1. Overall pedestrian traffic did not significantly change after vaccine availability, but larger groups (4+ people) became more common.

2. Lower-income areas consistently showed higher pedestrian traffic, likely due to reduced work-from-home options.

3. Areas with higher proportions of white residents showed increased pedestrian activity, possibly reflecting differences in risk perception or adherence to public health guidelines.

These findings demonstrate the potential of our method to capture nuanced changes in urban mobility patterns that may be missed by other data sources.

The broader impacts of this research are significant. Our open-source pipeline enables researchers, urban planners, and policymakers to collect detailed, timely data on community mobility and urban environments. This has applications in:

1. Public health: Monitoring adherence to social distancing guidelines and evaluating the impact of interventions.

2. Disaster response: Assessing recovery progress through changes in pedestrian activity and built environments.

3. Urban planning: Tracking changes in street usage, business activity, and neighborhood characteristics over time.

4. Social equity research: Identifying disparities in mobility patterns and access to public spaces across different communities.


Last Modified: 07/30/2024
Modified by: Joseph Wartman
